libk module¶

libk.check_PB(P, B)¶
libk.emffit(logB0, P, emf, V, hindex, E00, V0, T00, buret, fRTnF=25.67968, **kwargs)¶

Routine for Potentiometry data fitting. Based in Hyperquad (P. Gans, A. Sabatini, A. Vacca, Talanta 1996, 43, 1739-1753 and references therein.)

Input: (1) ‘logB0’ : [1D-array of floats] initial guess for the constants in the form

of log10.

  1. ‘P’ : [2D-array of ints] model proposed

  2. ‘emf’: [list of float 1D-array] containing emf measured in mV.

  3. ‘V’: [list of float 1D-array] containing volumes in mL

  4. ‘hindex’: [int or list of Nd-ints]. Index for the electrode sensitive #

    species (usually, the proton H+) default is -1 (the last one)

  5. ‘E00’: [list of floats] Value for standard potential for each curve in mV

  6. ‘V0’: [list of floats] Initial volume in mL

  7. ‘T00’: [list of (Nt, S)-arrays of floats] Total amounts of species in mmol

  8. ‘buret’: [list of (Nt, S)-arrays] Concentration of every species in

buret, in mmol/mL
  1. ‘fRTnF’: float or list of Nd-floats. by default 25.67968mV (1 atm,
298K, 1 electron, f=1). It float, assume it is the same value for all sets and internally converted into a list.
  1. ‘**kwargs’ [dict] : extra parameters and flags, specially refinement flags

Valid values are: - B_flags: - E0_flags: - T0_flags: - logB: False by default. If true B0 is assumed to be the log10 of the

constants to be refined
  • debug: returns a text with debug information
libk.esfit(Am, P, B, extc0, T)¶

Electronic Spectrum Fit.

Input: (1) ‘Am’: Absorbance measured. (2) ‘P’ : model proposed (3) ‘B’ : initial guess for the constants (4) ‘extc0’ : known values for extintion coefficients of None otherwise (5) ‘T’ : total concentrations of each component in each point

libk.nmrfit(delta_obs, T, P, B0, B_mask, d0, d_mask, X)¶
See from C. Frassineti, S. Ghelli, P. Gans, A. Sabatini,
    1. Moruzzi and A. Vacca, Anal. Biochem. 1995, 231, 374-382
Function to minimise:

U = Σ_j w_j(δ_calc - δ_obs) δ_calc = Σ_j(f_j.d_j) where

d_j chemical shift of a particular nucleus in the various species
present.
f_j = x_j . C_j/T_x
T_x is the total concentration of reagent containing the nucleus
under consideration

x_j is the stoichiometric coefficient X in the j_th species

libk.residuals(fm, fc, w=None)¶
This function defines the minimum square fitting scheme which always should be
$$chi^2 = sum{w(f_m - f_c)^2}$$

where $w$ are the weights for each data, $f_m$ is the measured property value and $f_c$ is the calculated one. Return value should be a float number.
